title: BBC World Service presenter Julian Keane dies after long illness
text:
Julian Keane worked for the BBC’s World Service for more than 30 years

The BBC has paid tribute to journalist and presenter Julian Keane who has died after a long illness.

Mr Keane worked for the World Service for more than 30 years, starting his career with the BBC’s French Service, then on Europe Today, The World Today and The Newsroom.

Most recently, Julian presented Newsday, since the programme’s launch in 2012.

He first joined the company in 1988 on an apprenticeship and went on to become one of the World Service’s most recognisable voices.

In a tribute package put together by colleagues, the BBC said: ‘As well as being a warm, calm and surefooted presence in the studio, Julian also presented the programme from a long list of countries, often finding himself in the middle of some of the biggest news stories we’ve covered.

Julian presented Newsday since the programme’s launch in 2012

‘By way of a tribute, this clip features Julian reporting in the Democratic Republic of Congo in the run-up to elections, in Venezuela as the full scale of the economic crisis began to emerge, and in the Central African Republic at the height of the violence between rival militias.

‘It begins in Zimbabwe as the 37 year rule of Robert Mugabe had came to and end.’

His colleague Jackie Leonard tweeted: ‘Such sad news. Julian was a brilliant broadcaster and a genuinely lovely man. We will miss him.’

A listener added: ‘What a voice. I remember him being the voice of the global news pod way back in 2007.’
